post_info.post_title: Gas prices...are they really that bad?

georged

I don't know what they're complaining about; diesel here is $3.02/gal and premium $2.89. As our image of a bully continues, inflation increases and China's requirements expand, we should easily hit $4/gal next year, maybe $5 by the end of 2006.
gamehuis
No, gas prices are not that bad. Around here we pay more than $6,- per gallon and the country is still functioning. Just buy a car that doesn't rate it's fuel efficiency in gallons per mile. ;)
georged

No, gas prices are not that bad. Around here we pay more than $6,- per gallon and the country is still functioning. Just buy a car that doesn't rate it's fuel efficiency in gallons per mile. ;)

 
 US vehicle manufacturers are still stuck in the mindset that they know best what's good for their customers. That's the reason Ford/GM were just downgraded to junk bond status by the remaining rating agency. 
 
 Let's see, the new formula for Ford/GM is now employee level discounts to all buyers, cash back or subsidized financing. That generated new sales which would have been for new models, but was rationalized by 'clearing out 2005 models'. Maybe I'm missing something, but in times of negative profitability and falling credit ratings, the normal reaction is to increase margin, not reduce it. Unless one is raising operating cash before putting it in chapter. I still eventually see enormous fields of repossessed giant SUVs parked before being crushed.
deathlord52

US vehicle manufacturers are still stuck in the mindset that they know best what's good for their customers. That's the reason Ford/GM were just downgraded to junk bond status by the remaining rating agency. 
 
 Let's see, the new formula for Ford/GM is now employee level discounts to all buyers, cash back or subsidized financing. That generated new sales which would have been for new models, but was rationalized by 'clearing out 2005 models'. Maybe I'm missing something, but in times of negative profitability and falling credit ratings, the normal reaction is to increase margin, not reduce it. Unless one is raising operating cash before putting it in chapter. I still eventually see enormous fields of repossessed giant SUVs parked before being crushed.

 More like the consumer wanted the massive, protection-inspiring feel of the road hog SUVs, and the US producers saw the cash cow status of these vehicles. And fuel prices were such that most did not care. Now that fuel has increased 200% in cost in about a decade, people are changing. And the US mfgrs - with no real nonSUV product - are paying the price.
 
 Much of GM's junk status has to do w/their moronic dealings w/the union. EVERY vehicle GM produces costs $1500 for just the health insurance premiums, and every year it gets worse (not to mention every % of mkt share lost). Ford has it bad as well on that front, just not as much. Add to that the fact that GM is killing off their new car designs to shore up the SUVs w/a quick redesign release the next 2 years, and their future is bleak. They will not disappear from a bankruptcy, but they will be smaller than Toyota (and maybe even Ford) when they come back.
daewoo

No, gas prices are not that bad. Around here we pay more than $6,- per gallon and the country is still functioning. Just buy a car that doesn't rate it's fuel efficiency in gallons per mile. ;)

 
 Yes, but that is already built into your economy. Most of that $6 per gallon is taxes. In the Us we pay the same taxes, they just distribute them differently. The entire US system is based on the availability of cheap energy. Take that away and the whole house of cards falls down.
Black Phoenix

Gas prices are insane. First the whole deal with hurrican Katrina was a load of XXXX. It affected only 10% of our gas supply.....90% was well in tact which was found in some congressional hearing over the Katrina issues. 
 
 My dad use to work down in the oil fields in Texas for like 5 years and has a bunch of buddies that work for Mobil, BP, and all over now. They were all saying it was a load of XXXX because most fuel found in the Gulf is Natural Gases...hmmm......
 
 Today on Mancow...they were saying that some company like Xenon or something made a 11 billion dollar profit over the past quarter while gas prices rose....
 
 How is there such a huge profit when we're supposedly "just getting by" with what oil we have left. 
 
 This XXXX that's going on with Katrina is the same thing that happened when we first took over Iraq and the rebels were burning oil fields. They tried to make a big jump in gas prices till the news came out with a report that we get most of gas from other places like Venezuela.
 
 I honestly believe this is just a means to increase profits for the big guys and see how far they push the economy before it buckles. 
 
 Of course I don't have a degree in economics....yet.
jim's trucking

I won't argue with anything you've said here except to say that I heard it was 25% of our domestic production that comes from the GoM.
 
 The oil companies posted record profits recently...something like 15 BILLION!
 
 Any old reason to raise the prices will work for them. Getting the prices to drop is like trying to squeeze blood out of a turnip! It's greed in action!
Captain America banned

I won't argue with anything you've said here except to say that I heard it was 25% of our domestic production that comes from the GoM.
 
 The oil companies posted record profits recently...something like 15 BILLION!
 
 Any old reason to raise the prices will work for them. Getting the prices to drop is like trying to squeeze blood out of a turnip! It's greed in action!

 
 I'll second that!
 
 And until we can pry the death grip the oil industry has firmly entrenched in Washington and especially in the oval office, I fear we have not seen the worst of it yet. emoticon_cry
georged

I won't argue with anything you've said here except to say that I heard it was 25% of our domestic production that comes from the GoM.
 
 The oil companies posted record profits recently...something like 15 BILLION!
 
 Any old reason to raise the prices will work for them. Getting the prices to drop is like trying to squeeze blood out of a turnip! It's greed in action!

 
 Our domestic production is about 40% of our consumption, so that would be 10% of requirements? Gulf refining capabilities were diminished by Katrina, including pipelines that serve the East and S. East states, which pushed gas futures up in price. 
 
 Oil company profit margin percentages aren't excessive. Traders are making big bucks, but the numbers you quote are total profits and without a margin percentage, meaningless. Volume is what makes those numbers big, not unusual considering we (US) consume 25% of world oil production.
georged

I'll second that!
 
 And until we can pry the death grip the oil industry has firmly entrenched in Washington and especially in the oval office, I fear we have not seen the worst of it yet. emoticon_cry

 
 That political aspect will be our undoing. Once USD is no longer the common medium of exchange for oil, our 'selling' USD in the form of debt, the cash flow that now keeps our fiscal head above water, will no longer be a required
 purchase for other countries.
Dono

I keep hearing references to "corporate greed". I worked for several corporations, large and small, and they all had a common reason for existing and a common goal ..... to make money. In my opinion, any business that does not maximize profits within the boundaries set by law is poorly run.
 Dono
georged

I keep hearing references to "corporate greed". I worked for several corporations, large and small, and they all had a common reason for existing and a common goal ..... to make money. In my opinion, any business that does not maximize profits within the boundaries set by law is poorly run.

 I often get the feeling that many posters who yell corporate greed have little or no private sector experience beyond maybe a paycheck regarding purpose of a corporation. Or what it takes to grind out that paycheck.

 http://carolinajournal.com/opinions/display_story.html?id=2729
 
 
 ...

 
 I read the opening of that article and burst out laughing:
 
 
Gasoline prices are high. Prices everywhere are well above $2 a gallon for regular-grade gasoline, and most motorists are paying more than $2.50.

 
 Two dollars fifty cents? Jeez, you are hard done by, I mean I only have to pay $6.30 over here emoticon_rolleyes
mtm1963

Prices peaked at $3.29 a gallon in my end of town.
 
 Price is now down to $2.89 a gallon.
 
 Speculation about shortages and bad weather are reasons why the price has been driven so high by the market. 
 
 I can't remember a time when the weather forecast had such an influence on driving up energy prices in the manner that we seen since last winter and now today with the hurricane.
 
 mtm1963
RedMoon

I read the opening of that article and burst out laughing:
 
 Two dollars fifty cents? Jeez, you are hard done by, I mean I only have to pay $6.30 over here emoticon_rolleyes

 
 I'm assuming "over here" refers to Europe, where the public transportation systems are world-class, easily accessible, and it is actually possible to live without an automobile. 
 
 In the United States, cities are spread across dozens of miles, connected by highways, and generally devoid of any sort of remotely convenient or reliable public transportation. There are few cities in the US with any form of reasonable public transport, which means nearly everyone is forced to drive everywhere they go.
 
 I'd happily pay $6/gallon for gas if I could have a guaranteed and reliable public transportation system. I'm probably in a minority there.
Jo Bennett

I'm assuming "over here" refers to Europe, where the public transportation systems are world-class, easily accessible, and it is actually possible to live without an automobile. 
 
 In the United States, cities are spread across dozens of miles, connected by highways, and generally devoid of any sort of remotely convenient or reliable public transportation. There are few cities in the US with any form of reasonable public transport, which means nearly everyone is forced to drive everywhere they go.
 
 I'd happily pay $6/gallon for gas if I could have a guaranteed and reliable public transportation system. I'm probably in a minority there.

 
 World class is not a phrase I would use to describe our public transport system. Sure there are some countries, Switzerland for example, that have good systems, but the UK public transport network is dying on its arse from lack of investment, and privatisation. Even with petrol prices as they are once you have a car it is almost always cheaper to use a car than take a train or bus, and it is quicker. I can't drive and couldn't afford a car even if I could, and hence I do rely on public transport, I can emphatically tell you that it is not world class, nor is it comprehensive. As a student I live in an area with pretty good transport links, and can buy a years pass for local buses for ~GBP160, but not all areas are this well served.
Alan Ryan

Sure there are some countries, Switzerland for example, that have good systems. 

 You are correct: Switzerland has an excellent public transport system - the best I've ever had the pleasure of using. But it is not cheap. I recently travelled from Interlaken to Lucerne (a distance of 51 miles) and paid the equivalent of £29 for the day return journey in 2nd class - that's about $50. 
 
 Any journey to a tourist "hot spot" in Switzerland is very expensive.
JPSartre12

I'm assuming "over here" refers to Europe, where the public transportation systems are world-class, easily accessible, and it is actually possible to live without an automobile. 
 
 In the United States, cities are spread across dozens of miles, connected by highways, and generally devoid of any sort of remotely convenient or reliable public transportation. There are few cities in the US with any form of reasonable public transport, which means nearly everyone is forced to drive everywhere they go.
 
 I'd happily pay $6/gallon for gas if I could have a guaranteed and reliable public transportation system. I'm probably in a minority there.

 
 That's an understatement. Americans have a much greater car culture than the rest of the developed world. We've been spoiled with lots of open spaces, good highway systems and plenty of parking, not to mention cheap gas prices.
